results.title: Fires of the mind: workings of the human brain
results.creator_credit: Chip Walter, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Infinite voyage”.
Outlines findings of current research into the workings of the human brain - its anatomy and physiology, discoveries concerning its evolution and research into such areas as memory, the sense of self, and the human mind’s ability to reflect upon itself.

group_siblings.title: Unseen worlds: imaging from atoms to outer space
group_siblings.creator_credit: Steve Eder, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED

results.title: Unseen worlds: imaging from atoms to outer space
results.creator_credit: Steve Eder, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Infinite voyage”.
Examines a wide range of imaging techniques and their many and varied applications, such as anthropologists using computer technology to probe the remains of Egyptian mummies to discover previously unknown facts about the health and life-style of these people, or doctors using magnetic imaging to view the brain and other organs to provide treatment without resorting to invasive techniques like exploratory surgery.

results.title: Classic tales; English Gentlemen
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The Best of British”.
The ultimate collection of scenes from feature films inspired by the literary giants Shakespeare, Shaw, Dickens, Wilde and Wells. Some of the great classic films based on literature are featured including “Oliver Twist”, “Caesar and Cleopatra” and ‘The Importance of being Earnest’. In the episode entitled the “English gentlemen”, the image of this stereotype as portrayed in film is discussed. It is a reflection on the urbane and sometimes eccentric characters portrayed by such stars as Rex Harrison, Michael Wilding and Stanley Holloway. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Heaven and earth; Love story
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “The Best of British”.
Heaven and Earth looks at how religion has provided British films with stories that have been dramatic, controversial and inspirational including classics like “Black narcissus” and “Conspiracy of hearts.” “Love story” looks at why there will always be an audience for great film love stories such as “Romeo and Juliet”, “Brief encounter”, and “Seventh veil.” Narrated by by Sir John Mills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors

results.title: All at sea; Film fun
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Best of British”.
All at sea focuses on the fine English tradition for “messing about in boats.” This episode explores action on the high sea from intrepid explorers like Columbus to heroes in submarines, as well as those heroic sea sagas and comic “fun on the ocean waves” films. “Film fun” highlights the visual comedy from Britain’s rich source of comedians such as Norman Wisdom, Frankie Howard, Peter Sellers and the Carry On crew who demonstrate the art of immaculate timing and pure visual technique. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Reel lives; All in the game
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series ‘The Best of British’.
Great historical characters have been portrayed on the silver screen since the movies began. The veracity of these films ranges from the authentic to sheer flights of fantasy. In ‘Reel lives’, films such as ‘The Magic bow’ starring Stewart Granger, and ‘Cleopatra’ with Vivien Leigh are examined. ‘All in the game’ discusses how sports provided just the right background to some of the most exciting British films, including the famous ‘This sporting life’ and ‘The Lady vanishes’. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: I Spy. The English roses
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Best of British”.
I spy is a fascinating compilation of British spy films such as Alfred Hitchcock’s “The Lady vanishes”. Included is an interesting comparative analysis of the 1935, 1959 and 1978 versions of “The 39 steps.” “The English roses” spotlights six of Britain’s most beautiful and talented leading actresses in a range of roles which won the hearts of many viewers. Actresses covered include Deborah Kerr, Phyllis Calvert, Margaret Lockwood, Jean Simmons, Patricia Roc and Virginia McKenna. Narrated by Sir John Mills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors

results.title: Fine and dandy; Things that go bump in the night
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Best of British”.
Fine and dandy illustrates the fame of British costume dramas in all their lavishness. A wonderfully romantic outcome was the main feature of these films which focused on the purity of love, whether the character was a lusty lord or a defenceless maiden. From malevolent spirits to demonic murderers, benevolent ghosts to spooky fortune tellers, British horror films will have you screaming and laughing in turn. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The all singing all dancing show; Power and prejudice
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Best of British”.
The All singing all dancing show features a time when Britain produced screen musicals that were innovative, exciting and visually stunning. This episode uncovers jewels with scenes from films like “The Red shoes” and “London town”, and a host of stars including Jessie Matthews, Kay Kendall and Moira Shearer. “Power and Prejudice” focuses on films that reflect social attitudes, struggles and problems of ordinary people. Narrated by Sir John Mills.
